column2: I am being forced to purchase a new device as all US networks are apparently no longer supporting Huawei devices in the very near future. I decided to give the Note a try as it seemed that it would keep up with my daily usage for work and I've always desired having the S pen.

column1: I've been using this phone for a few days now and it is soooooo slow. Apps and Google searches take way too long to load. Hotspot is just downright awful. Battery life is sub par. Fast charging is much slower than what I had. Camera doesn't quite compare to my old phone's Leica camera
column2: which I figured it wouldn't. Not sure what kind of scam this is but I'm definitely returning it. Also didn't come with earbuds or the phone clone connector. Don't get me wrong
column3: the phone looks great. The S pen was everything I was hoping for. The screen is spectacular and super bright. The 120hz refresh rate was cool for maybe the first 10 sec
column4: then I realized it was a pretty worthless feature. Scrolling to the end of long page in a few seconds does me no good when I'm trying to read posts or search for information on that page.

column1: I went to AT&T to get my phone diagnosed. He tested it against his Note 20 Ultra and his phone ended up being twice as fast as mine running the same speed test
column3: on the same unlimited plan... all after my device took an additional 10-15 sec to connect before even starting the test.

column2: don't waste your money. Just because Samsung markets like crazy doesn't mean their phones are any good. For a flagship device and the price point
column3: this phone falls well short of being worth it. I came from a two year old Huawei Mate 20 Pro and it's sad that Samsung can't make a phone that is able to compete with it. Not what I expected for my first Note phone. I've never been a Samsung hater by any means
column4: but this experience just solidifies my previous viewpoint to never buy a Samsung device. Won't make that mistake again.

column1: I made that mistake again... In my defense

column3: it was not. That device had all the same issues. Slow network speeds with AT&T (I live in a major city so this shouldn't happen
column4: period). This phone also didn't come with earbuds so it seems like Samsung is just getting cheap on consumers.

column1: I tried swapping the SIM card with my girlfriend's S20 and it still didn't work. All calls were sent directly to voicemail and text messages were very hit or miss. AT&T had no idea
column2: but I'm sure it was out of the hourly employees realm to troubleshoot. I had to switch back to my Huawei Mate 20 Pro. After 10 min or so I got a couple delayed text messages that were sent days ago in response to a text I originally sent from the Note 20 Ultra. SMH...

column1: I'm just downright confused at this point. Not sure whether it's an issue with the device or with the 5G network
